rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:21
rsbNotes.text: 9:21 Naboth the Jezreelite. Jehu’s coup reaches its climax at the very place Ahab and Jezebel had Naboth killed (1 Kin. 21:1–16).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:22
rsbNotes.text: 9:22 What peace. Jehu’s question addresses the heart of the issue. There can be no true peace where there is idolatry and witchcraft (cf. 17:17; 21:6; Judg. 2:17; 8:33; Hos. 2; 3; Nah. 3:4).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:25
rsbNotes.text: 9:25 the Lord made this pronouncement against him. See 1 Kin. 21:21–24.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:27
rsbNotes.text: 9:27 Ahaziah the king of Judah . . . died. Jehu was not authorized to kill the descendants of David who were related to the house of Ahab through his daughter Athaliah (cf. vv. 8–10). Jehu was too zealous in carrying out his commission. Hosea criticizes him for “the blood of Jezreel” (Hos. 1:4).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:29
rsbNotes.text: 9:29 In the eleventh year. This figure may count only the whole years of his reign, leaving out the year he took the throne. This would agree with the figures given in 8:25.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:30
rsbNotes.text: 9:30 Jezreel. Again the scene of action ominously returns to the site of Naboth’s murder.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:31
rsbNotes.text: 9:31 Zimri. In referring to Jehu in this way, Jezebel is sarcastically alluding to Zimri’s bloody purge almost half a century earlier (1 Kin. 16:9–15).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:32
rsbNotes.text: 9:32 eunuchs. This word could refer to men who were employed as guards and attendants of royal harems in the ancient Near East (as here) or to officials who served in the royal court (20:18; Is. 39:7; Jer. 29:2; 34:19; 38:7; Dan. 1:3, 7–10).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:34
rsbNotes.text: 9:34 a king’s daughter. Jehu does not dignify Jezebel with the title Queen of Israel, but refers to her as the daughter of Ethbaal, the Sidonian king (1 Kin. 16:31).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 9:36
rsbNotes.text: 9:36 dogs shall eat the flesh of Jezebel. The judgment oracle Jezebel so contemptuously scorned in her life is now fulfilled in her death (1 Kin. 21:23). Dogs were also present at Ahab’s death (1 Kin. 22:38).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:1
rsbNotes.text:
10:1 seventy sons. This figure probably included grandsons. How many wives (1 Kin. 20:5) Ahab had is not known.

elders. See note 1 Kin. 8:1.

guardians of the sons. These guardians were responsible for bringing up and educating children in the royal household. The king was dead and Jehu addressed various lesser figures.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:5
rsbNotes.text:
10:5 over the palace. See note 1 Kin. 4:6.

over the city. This position is similar to the “governor of the city” in 1 Kin. 22:26.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:6
rsbNotes.text: 10:6 take the heads of your master’s sons. Jehu’s demand takes the form of a pun. In Hebrew “head” can mean part of the body or it can mean “leader” or “chief.” It is uncertain whether Jehu is asking for the death of all Ahab’s male descendants, or for the leaders among the royal princes.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:7
rsbNotes.text: 10:7 slaughtered . . . seventy persons. The leaders of Samaria take no chances; they carry out Jehu’s command literally. In this way another component of Elijah’s prophecy comes to pass (1 Kin. 21:21–24).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:8
rsbNotes.text: 10:8 Lay them in two heaps. Assyrian kings, like Ashurbanipal and Shalmaneser III, intimidated populations by leaving heaps of heads by the city gates.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:11
rsbNotes.text: 10:11 Jehu struck down all. Jehu’s actions went far beyond the mandate of Elijah’s oracle (1 Kin. 21:21–24) and the oracle delivered personally to Jehu (9:7–10).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:12
rsbNotes.text: 10:12 Beth-eked of the Shepherds. Probably located a few miles northeast of Jenin.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:13
rsbNotes.text: 10:13 relatives of Ahaziah. These relatives do not realize that a coup has taken place.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:15
rsbNotes.text: 10:15 Jehonadab the son of Rechab. He was from a family or clan in Israel that led a life of austerity and abstinence. Following their convictions about worshiping God, the Rechabites did not plant fields or drink wine (Jer. 35).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:18
rsbNotes.text: 10:18 Ahab served Baal a little, but Jehu will serve him much. Jehu’s ruse was designed to entice Baal supporters to reveal their allegiance publicly. Having utterly destroyed the house of Ahab (v. 17), Jehu now begins his purge of Baal worship in Israel.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:21
rsbNotes.text: 10:21 the house of Baal. Ahab built this structure in Samaria (1 Kin. 16:32).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:26
rsbNotes.text:
10:26 the pillar. See note 1 Kin. 14:23.

burned it. Stone monuments can be shattered by heating them with fire and then pouring cold water on them.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:27
rsbNotes.text: 10:27 made it a latrine. This desecrated the site and discouraged any future Baal worshipers from trying to rebuild their temple.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 10:31
rsbNotes.text: 10:31 law of the Lord. On the importance of keeping the law, see note 1 Kin. 2:3.
